pages:
STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
August 18, 2023
Timothy Nelson
KENT COUNTY JUVENILE DETENTION CENTER
1501 CEDAR ST,
GRAND RAPIDS, MI, 49503-1300
Re: License #: CO410201223
Investigation# 2023C0000596
Dear Timothy Nelson:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• Repeat violations.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact Jessica VandenHeuvel, the area manager at (616) 204-
6992.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Paul Fatato, Licensing Consultant
enclosure

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
SPECIAL INVESTIGATION REPORT

Licensee Group Organization: 17th Circuit Court Family Division
Licensee Designee: Timothy Nelson
Chief Administrator: Timothy Nelson
Agency Name: KENT COUNTY JUVENILE DETENTION
CENTER

GRAND RAPIDS, MI 49503-1300

License Expiration Date: 10/01/2023
Capacity: 98

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & COF Rule 400.10123 Staff Sufficiency
Section (1) A facility shall have a staffing pattern of administrative,
Description supervisory, direct care, and other staff sufficient to perform the
prescribed functions required by these administrative rules and to
provide for the needs, protection, and supervision of the residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff 1 is an employee. Staff 1 is hitting the youth. She has
physically struck a few children. Staff 1 isn't doing this to cause
2

harm however it is in a bullying manner. This is not resulting in
any injuries. There have been multiple occurrences and the exact
date and times are unknown. In the gym, Staff 1 had a resident
against the wall with a drawn fist.
Investigation Administrator 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility, on
7/5/2023. He reported having a meeting with Staff 4/Complainant
on 7/3/23 for her performance. During this meeting Staff 4 shared
that she is struggling with her temper and needs help. Staff
4/Complainant also reported Staff 1 has been hitting the youth and
struggles with boundary issues involving the youth. The reported
incidents were to have taken place on the Gamma unit where
Staff 1 works. Administrator 1 encouraged her to complete a
3200-report form and she informed him she has made the report
to DHHS. Administrator 1 also reported moving Staff
4/Complainant to another unit. Administrator 1 was interviewed
again face to face at the facility on 7/18/23 in collaboration
with MDHHS worker. He reported speaking to Staff 1 and her
informing him she has been playful with the youth. Staff 1
informed him she had hit youth in the stomach, shoulder, and arm
on different occasions but only in a playful way. Administrator 1
reported these behaviors by Staff 1 are inappropriate. He
indicated the facility does not have a policy about staff being
specifically playful with youth.
Youth A was interviewed face to face at the facility, on
7/5/2023. He reported having no issues with Staff 1 and has been
treated fairly by her. He also reported Staff 4/Complainant picks
on the youth, talks about them in negative ways, and at times
doesn’t give snacks. He was unable to give specifics but did report
Staff 4/Complainant once threw his food away when he was not
done eating. Youth A feels safe at the facility.
Youth B was interviewed face to face at the facility, on
7/5/2023. He reported having no issues with staff and has not
observed any inappropriate behavior by staff. Staff 1 “is nice, tries
to help the kids, and talks to the youth a lot”. Youth B feels safe in
the facility.
Youth C was interviewed face to face at the facility, on
7/5/2023. He reported “love Staff 1 because she is like a strict
mom, holds us accountable and pours into our lives”. He also
reported Staff 4/Complainant has “messed with Youth A because
she will issue him a time-out even if he looks at her. The only
specific example was during a church service, Staff 4/Complainant
is reported to have taken Youth A out of church when he
questioned why he couldn’t ask a question. Youth C reported Staff
3

2 will target youth and give time-outs unfairly. He was unable to
identify any specific examples. Youth C reported feelings safe in
the facility. Youth C was interviewed again face to face at the
facility on 7/18/23 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. He
reported Staff 1 will hit the other youth but not him. He was smiling
and grinning when giving his report. Staff 1 hit Youth D, Youth E,
and Youth K in the stomach during a walk back from the gym
because they were looking at female youth. Youth C believed the
punch hurt them because they “curled up” and that this incident
occurred after June 25, 2023 on second shift. Youth C also
reported Staff 1 was not joking when she hit Youth D, Youth E,
and Youth K. Youth K “played off the hit” but later told Youth C he
was hurt. Youth C reported not telling everything in the first
interview because he didn’t want to get staff into trouble and
believed staff would “give us extra days in treatment”. He also
reported Staff 2 threatened one of the youth on his unit while in
the lunchroom.
Youth D was interviewed face to face at the facility, on
7/5/2023. He reported having no issues with staff and gets along
with Staff 1 well. “She pours into us and is very helpful.” He also
reported Staff 4/Complainant targets youth and the example is she
will tell other staff the youth are doing wrong by showing gang
signs when they are not. Youth D believed Staff 4/Complainant
tries to get the youth she doesn’t like into trouble. Youth D
reported feeling safe and the program is helping him change.
Youth D was interviewed again face to face at the facility on
7/18/23 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. He reported
always getting along with Staff 1 but having arguments with her
when he first entered the program. He also reported Youth E got
along with her until she was leaving the program for another unit.
He described the playing as a “hit on the arm or a fake punch”. He
reported to laugh about this playing and other youth would also
laugh while engaged in the playing. Youth D reported being the
only youth Staff 1 punched in the stomach when he looked at a
female youth after Staff 1 told the group not to look at the female
youth. He denied the punch hurt and believed Staff 1 was just
joking. He reported Youth E stopped getting along with Staff 1
when she was transferring from the unit and Youth C never got
along with her. He also reported not being sure if he observed
Staff 1 hit Youth E and he never observed her hit Youth C.
Youth E was interviewed face to face at the facility, on
7/5/2023. He reported the staff are good but will sometimes bully
the youth. He believes staff will “take it out on us” when they are in
a “bad mood”. He also reported Staff 1 will say things he doesn’t
4

agree with and during a group discussion she began to yell at him
for no reason. He stated, he thought it was an open discussion
group, so he started talking. After Staff 1 started yelling, he
stopped talking in an effort to control myself. He described Staff
1’s yelling as her tone of voice is “louder than normal” and she will
tell the youth if they don’t listen to her, they will end up back in the
facility. He also reported Staff 2 will not allow his unit to speak to
the unit she is working on and will give consequences to all the
youth if one youth does something wrong. He was unable to
provide specific examples. He also reported never witnessing any
staff strike a youth and feels safe at the facility. Youth E was
interviewed again face to face at the facility on 7/18/23 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. He reported not knowing
why he was being interviewed but was aware Youth C had filed a
grievance about Staff 1 hitting youth. Staff 1 punched Youth J
while in line and walking back from the gym to their unit. Youth E
reported Youth J started laughing and ran to the unit, but he was
unclear if this occurred when some of the youth were looking at
female youth from another unit. Youth E also reported he became
“scared” and also ran towards the unit and he believes this took
place towards the end of June. When Youth E reached the unit
and sat down in a chair, Staff 1 came and “punched” him in the
back, and it hurt him. He was unsure if she was serious or joking.
He was unable to remember different staff engaging in “fake
punching” and was unable to recall when Staff 1 hit Youth C.
Youth E also reported Youth C, Youth G, and himself did not get
along with Staff 1 because she would “pick on us and lower our
points if we were laughing at the table”. Youth E reported hearing
Staff 1 say if the youth were her children she would “whoop” them.
He overheard Staff 2 and Staff 3 say they “would jump some other
youth like us”.
Youth F was interviewed face to face at the facility, on
7/5/2023. He reported some youth are writing grievances about
staff showing favoritism, but he is unsure who the youth are, and
he has never seen staff show favoritism. He reported Staff 1 is
able to tell how youth are feeling about things. He reported Staff
4/Complainant “wears me out at times” and will blame the unit
when it is another unit doing the behavior. He was unable to
provide a specific example but that this occurs when the two units
are in the gym.
Youth G was interviewed face to face at the facility, on
7/5/2023. He reported Staff 1 is stern, but he understands “she is
a women and has to be right all the time”. He also reported Staff 1
will say things to youth and they will shut down. He believes she
5

gets upset and becomes “misguided at times” because she cares
to much for the youth. Youth G reported tension between Staff 1
and Staff 4/Complainant because Staff 1 believed Staff
4/Complainant was targeting the unit where Youth G was lodged.
He believes the tension has been solved. Youth G also reported
overhearing Staff 2 and Staff 3 say they were going to jump a
youth in the lunchroom and jump a youth in the parking lot. He
also reported Staff 2 and Staff 3 treat youth unfairly and show
favoritism by giving some youth a pass on consequences. He
reported feeling safe at the facility. Youth G was interviewed
again face to face at the facility on 7/18/23 in collaboration
with MDHHS worker. He reported not “caring for Staff 1” because
he has the same issues with Staff 1, he has with his mother. He
described these issues as Staff 1 telling others he was having a
hard time with his leadership role and doesn’t accept her help.
Youth G also reported Staff 1 has told the youth they would return
to the facility if they don’t make the changes, she thinks they
should make. Youth G observed Staff 1 take a swing at Youth J
when he said something smart to her, but he was not sure if she
connected. He also observed Staff 1 hit Youth J another time. He
observed Staff 1 hit Youth D in the stomach when he was looking
at the female youth on the way back from the gym and hit Youth E
in the back during a card game. Youth G also reported over
hearing Staff 2 and Staff 3 saying something about if youth act like
that on the outs they would get jumped. He was unsure if they
were joking or not.
Staff 2 was interviewed face to face at the facility, on 7/5/2023.
She reported limited working experience with Staff 1 but never
hearing the youth complain about Staff 1. She also reported youth
have complained about Staff 4 telling her she antagonizes them
and will bully them. She admitted to not observing this but hearing
it from other unidentified youth. Staff 2 reported unidentified youth
also tell her they feel Staff 4/Complainant looks at them as less
than herself and Staff 4 will not allow them to express their
emotions. Staff 2 denied she has targeted any youth but when she
holds them accountable, “it’s a shock to them”. She reported the
youth will believe she is “trying to tear down their world” when she
gives them a consequence. Staff 2 described herself as treating
everyone the same and being a “very stern person of facts”. She
reported the incident in the lunchroom involved Youth I and Staff
3. She also reported it was “all jokes and games and would never
go any further. She reported jumping someone was part of a joke.
Staff 3 was interviewed face to face at the facility, on 7/5/2023.
He reported Youth J made a joke about knocking off Staff 3’s
6

glasses and Staff 3 responded with “you’re going to knock my
glasses off”. Staff 2 entered the conversation at that time and Staff
3 told Staff 2, “if you go high, I will go low”. He reported this was
all in a joking manner. He also reported Youth G was wiping
tables and not involved in the conversation.
Youth H was interviewed face to face at the facility, on
7/5/2023. He reported he was joking around with Staff 3 in the
lunchroom and Staff 3 and himself “have gone back and forth just
once”. He described the situation as Staff 3 grabbing his shoulder
causing Youth H to laugh. Youth H responded by saying “come
back here again and I will knock your glasses off”. Youth H
reported Staff 3 was laughing about it. He also reported Staff 2
told him Staff 2 and Staff 3 are a team and if Staff 3 comes “Staff
2 will also come”. Youth H reported staff treat youth like they want
to be treated and he feels safe at the facility.
Youth I was interviewed face to face at the facility, on
7/5/2023. He reported not remembering the incident in the
lunchroom but also reported “playing around” with Staff 3 at times.
He described the playing as Staff 3 grabbing him by both
shoulders while he was standing in line. Youth I moved Staff 3’s
arms after this. He also reported feeling safe at the facility.
Supervisor 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility, on
7/5/2023. She reported Staff 1 is viewed as a mother figure by the
youth but that she has never observed Staff 1 doing anything
inappropriate. Supervisor 1 also reported never receiving reports
of Staff 1 hitting youth, but Supervisor 1 also believes Staff 1 is not
paying attention to the youth to the level she should be paying
attention. Supervisor 1 reported Staff 1 and Staff 4/Complainant
had issues between them, and Staff 1 and Staff 4/Complainant
had words one day in the breakroom. Supervisor 1 had Staff 1
and Staff 4/Complainant meet and work through their differences.
Staff 4/Complainant felt targeted by Staff 1 and met with
Supervisor 1 again to discuss these concerns. Staff
4/Complainant never brought up Staff 1 issues during this second
meeting.
Probation Officer 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility,
on 7/5/2023. She reported never receiving any reports from the
youth of Staff 1 nor any staff hitting them. She also reported
working with the youth lodged in the unit Staff 1 primarily works.
Probation Officer 1 was interviewed again face to face at the
facility on 7/18/23 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. She
reported calling in the second set of allegations after Youth E
7

reported to her during a therapy session, she had with him. Youth
E was feeling guilty for “not telling the truth” during the first
interview. Youth E also struggles with anxiety and mental illness
and believed staff would retaliate (not let him earn his days)
against him if he told what was really happening. Probation Officer
1 also reported Youth C wanted to tell something different than
during his first interview. She reported Youth E and Youth C both
informed her Youth J was slapped “very hard” in the face by Staff
1 and when Probation Officer 1 attended a graduation party for
Youth J, he confirmed this report. Probation Officer 1 had no more
information and was unable to identify when it may have taken
place. Youth E also identified Youth D and Youth K as having
information about Staff 1’s inappropriate behaviors. She never
observed Staff 1 with inappropriate behaviors towards the youth.
Probation Officer 2 was interviewed face to face at the facility,
on 7/5/2023. He reported having no knowledge of any reports of
Staff 1 nor any other staff hitting the youth. He also reported
working with the youth lodged in the unit Staff 1 primarily works.
Staff 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility, on 7/5/2023.
She reported the allegations are not true but that she does “joke
with the kids” at times. She denied ever holding a youth against
the wall while threatening to hit them. She also reported when
joking with the youth they will laugh, and this also includes any
“physical tussling” they might engage in. Staff 1 described the
tussling as “taping them on the hand”. Staff 1 reported having a
meeting with Staff 4/Complainant because she was upset that
Staff 4/Complainant told the youth, Staff 1 was not doing her job.
Staff 4/Complainant told the youth that Staff 1 is not holding the
youth accountable as required. Staff 1 believed everything was
worked out and Staff 4/Complainant was moved to another unit.
Staff 1 was interviewed again face to face at the facility on
7/18/23 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. She reported she
has “jokingly played with youth” and only engaged in behavior to
“motivate them”. When youth are not moving fast enough or
“popping off at the mouth”, she will try to motivate them, but the
youth have never reported to her they were getting hurt nor have
they asked her to stop. She also reported hitting youth on their
arms with no intent to harm and the youth always laugh and
responding back with a joke. This type of behavior only happens
on the unit she is working at the time, and she has observed other
staff grab youth by their shoulders in a playful manner or hug the
youth. She believes she is targeted because other staff do the
same thing and more but don’t’ get into trouble. She refused to
provide any specific information including the staff’s name and
8

suggested this playing between staff and youth happens often.
She denied the allegation of holding a youth against the wall with
her fist balled up. She reported this allegation is made up and she
has never done anything in a harmful way to the youth in her care.
She recalled an incident in the gym when two youth were upset
over a basketball game and after giving instructions to stop and
one youth didn’t stop, she issued a time out to the youth (unable
to recall the name of the youth), and he became upset. Staff 1
reported moving from the residential treatment unit to the
detention unit following the allegations of her not supervising the
youth appropriately (2023C0000425). She also reported receiving
positive feedback from several supports.
Staff 4/Complainant was interviewed via phone on 7/7/23. She
provided no further information on Staff 1 and repeated Staff 1 is
not harming the youth. She did identify the youth held against the
wall in the gym as Youth K. Staff 4/Complainant was
interviewed again face to face at the facility on 7/31/23 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. She identified Youth K as
the youth Staff 1 had against the wall before punching him in the
arm. She reported both Youth K and Staff 1 were smiling during
this reported encounter, but she believed Staff 1 punched Youth K
rather “hard”. Staff 4/Complainant also reported Staff 1 “smacked
Youth I on the hand” when he was reaching for Staff 1’s travel
coffee mug. This occurred on the unit. She denied ever observing
any other staff punch or strike a youth and believes all staff
understand they should not treat the youth in such a manner. She
reported being moved to another unit because she issued a youth
a time-out for making a gang sign that was not observed when a
video recording was reviewed by administration. She also
reported youth didn’t like her because she held them accountable,
and she was involved in a meeting with Administrator 1 where she
told him the truth about things in the facility. She has since
“mended” her relationship with Staff 1, and they are able to talk
now.
Supervisor 2 was interviewed face to face at the facility on
7/18/23 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. He reported
knowing Staff 1 “very well” and believes she “loves kids” and didn’t
believe there was “any foul behavior on Staff 1’s part”. He has
never observed any issues with Staff 1’s interactions with the
youth and had not had any staff report concerns about her. He
also reported telling staff not to touch youth and avoid playing
around with them. He only engages in fist bumps and no other
physical contact in a joking manner. Supervisor 2 reported the
youth don’t have an issue with Staff 1, but Staff 4/Complainant
9

has had an issue with Staff 1. Staff 4/Complainant becomes
dysregulated quickly and will pass off conflicts (need to issue a
time-out) to Staff 1. Supervisor 2 does not believe Staff
4/Complainant has the emotional stability to handle the issues the
youth present.
Staff 5 was interviewed face to face at the facility on 7/18/23
in collaboration with MDHHS worker. She reported working with
Staff 1 only once or twice and never observed her acting
inappropriately around the youth. Youth never shared concerns
about Staff 1 with Staff 5.
Staff 6 was interviewed face to face at the facility on 7/18/23
in collaboration with MDHHS worker. He reported working with
Staff 1 on several occasions and described her as “on point and
very solid, works well with the youth, and has a good relationship
with the youth”. He believes she puts her “best foot forward and is
able to take criticism well”. He denied observing Staff 1 hit the
youth but has observed her engage in a “tap as a greeting”. He
also reported the horseplay (joking) is wrong and that it violates
boundaries between youth and staff. He has observed staff
“horseplay and goof around” but does not engage in this type of
behavior himself.
Youth K was interviewed face to face at the facility on 7/18/23
in collaboration with MDHHS worker. He reported leaving the
facility on 6/30/23 and returning on 7/4/23. While on the unit Staff
1 was present during many of the second shifts on the unit. He
also reported he never had any issues with any of the staff
including Staff 1 but did observe staff engaging in joking around
with the youth. He described this joking around as play fighting
and joking when touching the youth. He also reported Staff 1
never hit any youth hard but always in a playful manner and Staff
1 once hit him in the upper chest but was just joking. Youth K
denied observing Staff 1 put a youth against the wall and attempt
to punch them. He reported never feeling unsafe while on the unit.
Youth J was interviewed via phone on 7/27/23 in collaboration
with MDHHS worker. He reported being hit in the face by Staff 1
towards the end of June and provided the following description.
“We were playing card and I talked loud so she smacked me in
the face”. He also reported Staff 1 played around and would hit
youth, but it was never too hard. He was present when Youth E
was punched by Staff 1 when they were on the unit and after the
incident of youth looking at female youth when returning from the
gym. Staff 1 punched Youth E under the rib cage and Youth J
10

could tell it hurt Youth E because Staff 1 put force behind the
punch. He reported Staff 1 threw a ball and hit Youth K in the
head but was unable to provide specifics about the incident. Youth
J reported Youth C was hit by Staff 1. Youth J reported Youth C
was hit for looking at female youth while standing in line but was
unsure where Youth C was punched. Youth J reported other staff
only fist bump and don’t hit youth like Staff 1 does. He also
reported feeling irritated by staff because they talk about him
behind his back.
Documents Reviewed:
Detention Procedures Manual – Resident Management 600.7
Dated 8/24/16. This document outlines the rights youth in the
facility have. The first right listed is youth shall be treated
respectfully, impartially, and fairly. The third right identified is
youth shall not be subject to intimidation, threats, humiliation.
Human Resources file for Staff 1 was reviewed. There was
documentation of disciplinary action against Staff 1 in the file. This
action took place following the special investigation
2023C0000425 in which she was found in violation of not
providing appropriate supervision of youth in her care and not
reporting suspected child abuse/neglect. She was also
substantiated by DHHS for this action. Documentation in the file
indicates, Staff 1 refused to sign the written reprimand presented
by Administrator 1 and Administrator 2. Administrator 1 during an
interview stated Staff 1 refused to sign because there were not 15
rapes reported but less. However, 15 rapes is what she reported
during her interviews. The corrective action Staff 1 is to be
involved in retraining on supervision of youth during shower times
and updated training on the new policy for mandated reporting.
Training records document Staff 1 completing new hire orientation
on 10/10/2022 and completing her policy reviews on 11/20/22 and
12/30/22. Her orientation training included but not limited to, job
duties/role/responsibilities, child management techniques,
discipline/de-escalation, and developmental needs of children.
Human Resources file for Staff 2 was reviewed. There was no
documentation of disciplinary action against Staff 2 documented in
the file. She was hired on 5/9/2022 and completed all
requirements of the orientation process. Documentation of her last
performance evaluation indicates she is meeting all the
requirements of her position. She is current on her training and
completed PREA/appropriate relationships with residents training
on 6/25/23.
11

Human Resources file for Staff 3 was reviewed. There was no
documentation of disciplinary action against Staff 2 documented in
the file. He was hired on 12/6/21 and completed all requirements
of the orientation process. Documentation of his last performance
evaluation indicates he is meeting all the requirements of his
position. He is current on his training and completed
PREA/appropriate relationships with residents training on 6/25/23.
Human Resources file for Staff 4 was reviewed. There was no
documentation of disciplinary action against Staff 4 documented in
the file. She was hired on 12/28/21 and completed all
requirements of the orientation process. Documentation of her last
performance evaluation indicates she requires improvement in the
requirements of her position. It is documented she needs to
improve her overall knowledge of her position and struggles,
becoming frustrated in applying the cognitive behavior techniques.
She is current on her training and completed PREA/appropriate
relationships with residents training on 5/17/23.
Second set of allegations provided by Probation Officer 1 on
7/7/23. “I talked with Youth E this afternoon and he shared that he
was scared to tell the investigator that was here from the state
about some of the incidents that he has experienced and
witnessed because he did not want it to make things worse for
him. Youth E shared that he personally has been punched by Staff
1 on two separate occasions but did not go into detail about
when/where these took place. He also shared that Youth C told
him that he wrote a grievance because he was also scared to
speak to the investigator. Youth E stated that he personally saw
Staff 1 slap and punch other residents, including Youth J (no
longer here), Youth C, and Youth K. Youth E stated that he
thought Staff 1 was "just playing around" but when she punched
him on the arm, "it really hurt."”
Analysis Based upon interviews and written documentation, evidence
supports Staff 1 did not provide for the needs, protection, and
supervision of the youth in her care.
Conclusion Violation Established
Rule Code & COF Rule 400.10107 Employment policies and procedures,
Section establishment
Description (1) A facility shall establish and follow written employment policies
and procedures that shall assure that staff are emotionally stable
and of suitable health, ability, experience, and education to
perform the duties assigned.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
12

Allegation During this investigation it was discovered that staff are engaging
in behaviors that go against the policy of staff being a role model.
Staff are also engaged in verbal (joking) and physical (playfighting
and hitting) horseplay.
Investigation Administrator 1 reported Staff 1 admitted to him she was engaged
in “playing” with the youth which involved her hitting the youth in a
“playful manner”.
Probation Officer 1 reported being told by Youth E of his
witnessing Staff 1 strike youth on different occasions.
Staff 1, Staff 4/Complainant, Youth C, Youth D, Youth E, Youth G,
Youth K, Youth J, all reported Staff 1 hit youth in a somewhat
playful manner to redirect their behaviors.
Youth G, Youth H, reported hearing Staff 2 and Staff 3 engage in
inappropriate talk and playing round with different youth. They are
reported to have told a youth they would jump him in the parking
lot and will grab youth by the shoulders.
Staff 2 and Staff 3 admitted to talking about jumping someone in
the parking lot and going high and going low on a youth but that it
was only a joke.
Documents Reviewed:
Administrative.1 Policy-Standards of Conduct. Dated
8/21/2021. This document outlines the conduct required by staff.
The first item address is staff are to act as role models of behavior
for the youth. Staff are not to show any conflict with other staff in
the presence of youth and to give respect to fellow staff as they
interact. Another aspect is to avoid jokes that may be interpreted
as counter to the expressed or implicit values of the facility.
Detention Procedures Manual – Resident Management 600.7
Dated 8/24/16. This document outlines the rights youth in the
facility have. The first right listed is youth shall be treated
respectfully, impartially, and fairly. The third right identified is
youth shall not be subject to intimidation, threats, humiliation.
Analysis Based upon interviews and written documentation, evidence
supports staff are not following the facilities policies and
procedures in regard to being role models for the youth lodged.
Staff and youth interviewed indicated some staff engage in this
type of physical horseplay (fake fighting) and verbal horseplay
(joking).
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE:
13

Development of more comprehensive policies that cover
boundaries between staff and youth. This should include
horseplay (physical and verbal) and physical touch.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established
2023C0328002 dated 11/21/22; CAP approved 12/1/22.
2023C0000425 dated 6/13/23; CAP approved 7/6/23.
IV. RECOMMENDATION
With an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that no change be
made to the license of this Court Operated Facility.
8/15/2023
